publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday May 7, 2019 at 03:13

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Dimension Records document the creation and publication of Dimension by its founder and editor, A. Leslie Willson. The collection contains subject files concerning authors and translators of German literature; drafts of writings and translations published in Dimension; drafts and proofs for Dimension, including most issues in volumes 1-19 and several special issues; subscription and other business records for Dimension; writings and translations of A. Leslie Willson; a small amount of records relating to Willson's work at the University of Texas and in professional organizations; photographs and slides of German authors and artists and their work; drawings and prints by German artists; and audio and audiovisual recordings, including Gruppe 47 conferences, author readings, radio plays, lectures, and interviews. Materials pertaining to Dimension document its history and funding; publication of authors, artists, and translators; and production of individual issues. Also present are correspondence, writings, photographs, and sound recordings concerning Willson's broader professional and personal relationships with German authors and academic colleagues. The collection is a resource for the study of German literature, art, and literary translation during the 1960s-1990s, as well as the teaching of German literature in American universities during the same period.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of A. Leslie Willson, 1996-2008. Gift of Juliet Willson Jimenez, Brian L. Willson, and Kevin R. Willson, 2008.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Boxes 68-69 (Teaching Materials): Restricted until 2085. For further information consult the appropriate curator.
Boxes 71-80 (Audiovisual Materials): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

Box 81 (computer disks): â€¡a Restricted fragile material. Reference copies are available for disks 4-6 and 8-11; reference copies for disks 1-3, 7, and 12-18 may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Dimension Records is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Dimension Records. Yale Collection of German Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The Dimension Records contain material formerly classed as Uncat Zg Ms 13. This baseline finding aid was prepared from preliminary lists made by the donor and the curator. For each series, any existing file groups were preserved, followed by related sorted and unsorted material. While most of the Archive has been rehoused, oversize galley proofs in Series II, Dimension Production Materials, have been left folded. In Series VI, Graphic Materials, a photograph album was dissasembled and slides were removed from original storage boxes. Some printed materials have been removed from the collection and cataloged individually in the Library's online catalog. Some duplicate or unmarked printed material, photocopies, and Dimension offprints were discarded by the curator before processing.

bioghist.head: Dimension
bioghist.p:
Dimension: Contemporary German Arts and Letters
was a bilingual German/English literary journal edited by A. Leslie Willson, professor of Germanic Studies at the University of Texas at Austin. Founded by Willson in 1968, Dimension was published through 1994 in a total of more than eighty regular and special issues. Willson stated that the goals of the journal were to improve the quality of translation and redress the time lag between the appearance of new literary writing in German and its availibility to English readers. Dimension published poems, plays, essays, short stories, radio plays, excerpts from novels, and drawings by hundreds of German-language authors and artists, including Peter Bichsel, Günter Grass, Gerhard Köpf, Günter Kunert, Siegfried Lenz, Ernst Jandl, Friederike Mayröcker, Gabriele Wohamnn, and Christa Wolf. Through publication of well-known authors, discovery of new authors, and collaboration between authors, translators, and editors,
Dimension
came to be regarded internationally as an influential forum for contemporary arts and letters.

Dimension
was funded by the University of Texas at Austin from its inception in 1968 through 1975. Funding was increasingly problematic after this, and when Willson's term as chairman of the University's German Department ended in 1980, he continued publication of Dimension without clerical or editorial support. Volumes 1-15:1 were designed and produced by the University of Texas Press at Austin. Starting with volume 15:2, Willson designed and produced the journal himself on an Apple computer. Dimension²: Contemporary German-language Literature, edited by Ingo R. Stoehr, began publication in 1994, continuing the format of the original journal.

bioghist.head: A. Leslie Willson
bioghist.p: A. (Amos) Leslie Willson (1923-2007), professor of German, author, editor, and translator, was born in Texas, studied journalism and German at the University of Texas at Austin, and earned a Ph.D. from Yale University in 1954. He was a member of the German Department faculty at the University of Texas at Austin, 1955-1961 and 1966-1992, and was emeritus professor of Germanic Languages, 1992-2007.

Willson's translations include novels by Michael Krüger ( The Man in the Tower and Himmelfarb ), Gerhard Köpf ( There is no Borges ; Papa's Suitcase ; Innerfar ; Bluff, or The Southern Cross ; Way to Eden ; Nurmi, or The Journey to the Trout ; and Piranesi's Dream ), and Ulla Berkéwicz ( Angels are Black and White ), and Hermann Kurzke's Thomas Mann: Life as a Work of Art . In addition to founding and editing Dimension , his work as an editor included several volumes of The German Library (Continuum Press). Willson co-founded the American Literary Translators Association in 1979 and was its first president. He served as president of the American Translators Association from 1991 to 1993.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Dimension Records document the creation and publication of Dimension by its founder and editor, A. Leslie Willson. The collection contains subject files concerning authors and translators of German literature; drafts of writings and translations published in Dimension ; drafts and proofs for Dimension , including most issues in volumes 1-19 and several special issues; subscription and other business records for Dimension ; writings and translations of A. Leslie Willson; a small amount of records relating to Willson's work at the University of Texas and in professional organizations; photographs and slides of German authors and artists and their work; drawings and prints by German artists; and audio and audiovisual recordings, including Gruppe 47 conferences, author readings, radio plays, lectures, and interviews. Materials pertaining to Dimension document its history and funding; publication of authors, artists, and translators; and production of individual issues. Also present are correspondence, writings, photographs, and sound recordings concerning Willson's broader professional and personal relationships with German authors and academic colleagues. The collection is a resource for the study of German literature, art, and literary translation during the 1960s-1990s, as well as the teaching of German literature in American universities during the same period.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into seven series: I. Subject Files. II. Dimension Production Materials. III. Dimension Business Records. IV. Writings. V. Personal Papers of A. Leslie Willson. VI. Graphic Materials. VII. Audiovisual Materials.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I, Subject Files, is organized into five subseries: Subject Files, circa 1962-1982; Subject Files, circa 1966-1988; Subject Files, 1970s; Other Subject Files; and Unsorted Subject Files. All subseries except Unsorted Subject Files are arranged alphabetically by folder title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Most subjects are authors, translators, or other colleagues associated with the production of Dimension . A few files of Dimension business records are present. Files typically contain correspondence with A. Leslie Willson, drafts of writings, and related printed material. The first three subseries are original file groups created by Willson; these are followed by additional files sorted by name and unsorted files. Original file groups date mostly circa 1962-1980, after which filing systems apparently were discontinued, probably due to lack of clerical assistance for the production of Dimension . Subject content and date spans therefore overlap among original file groups and later materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Most files are for translators, with some for literary agents and editorial associates. Many files are for American colleagues and contain materials relating to academic activity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Most files are for authors, with some for artists, translators, and other colleagues. Many files consist mainly or entirely of clippings and other printed material. Names are followed by date spans of materials; most materials date predominantly from the 1970s, reflecting Willson's work in mapping the German literary scene and solicitation of contributions for Dimension during that period.

Empty folders for the following names were discarded: Sophie Brandes, Walter Mathias Diggelmann, Roderick Feldes, Iring Fetscher, Wolfgang Fienhold, Wolfgang Gabel, Ulrich Greiner, Peter Grosz, Herbert Günter, Franz Haderer, Johannes Hübner, Paul Gerhard Hübsch, Lothar Klünner, Klaus Konjetzky; Hans Mans, Anneliese Meinert, Gina Ruck Pauquet, Ilse Pracht-Fitzell, Gerd Sonntag.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Kunert, Günter (with literary texts, a clipping file, and original photographs of Kunert)
Otto, Hans-Peter (1976; photographs of a literary conference, probably in Austin)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Most files concern authors and translators whose work was published in Dimension or was considered for publication, possibly with some unsolicited contributions. Contents consist of German texts, manuscript or photocopy; drafts or printer's copies of translations; and some Dimension offprints and other clippings. These files contain almost no correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Geerk, Frank (apparently early unpublished novel titled "Plastic, eine Apokalypse")
Kunert, Günter ("Gast aus England," photocopy of corrected typescript; poems; and short prose texts with translations)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Müller, Heiner (contains adaptation of Feydor Gladkov's play "Zement," English translation, possibly unpublished)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These files are a partial organization of materials left unsorted by Willson. More materials relating to the same names may be found in remaining unsorted files. Contents include drafts and proofs of works in progress, translations, and correspondence.

Leslie Willson

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Files consist of materials left unsorted by A. Leslie Willson, dating circa 1980s-2007. Contents relating to Dimension include texts, with author and translator correspondence; materials relating to special issues; and unsolicited contributions. Other contents relate to Willson's professional and personal correspondence, teaching, and work in professional organizations, including materials relating to the American Translators Association, the German Summer School in Taos, visiting authors at the University of Texas, and the Continuum Publishing Company's German Library series.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into subseries by Volume, followed by Special Issues, Microfilm, Dimension², and Unidentified.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Production materials for each issue typically include notes, correspondence, memoranda, marked-up typescripts, pasted-up art work, mock-ups, mechanicals, galley proofs and page proofs.
Related materials may be found in Series I, Subject Files, under names of authors and translators.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Records consist of original file groups of business and subscription records created by A. Leslie Willson, followed by unsorted files. Other related materials may be found in Series I, Subject Files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes records relating to the founding of Dimension , correspondence with University of Texas Dean W. Gordon Whaley about funding, correspondence with other funding agencies, financial accounts, and early distribution, subscription, and exchange lists.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Accounting files for contributors and subscribers to Dimension , including individuals, libraries, and other institutions. Includes some correspondence between Willson and subscribers. Files are labeled with names and identification numbers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Most writings are manuscripts, typescripts, or photocopies.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into five subseries: Writings by A. Leslie Willson; Translations by A. Leslie Willson; Translations by Jeanne Willson; Writings by Others; and Translations by Others. Within each subseries, writings are arranged alphabetically by title or genre; translations are arranged alphabetically by original author and title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Essays include: "The Portrait of Berlin in Lyric Poetry," "The Many Faces of Censorship in the Federal Republic of Germany," "Constancy and Variation: The Short Story in Germany," "German Literature in the Twentieth Century" (for Columbia Dictionary of Modern European Literature, 2nd edition), interview with Heinrich Böll, essays about literary translation
Some essays are accompanied by related correspondence and source materials
With a set of essays by other authors on the topic of translation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The first subseries contains materials relating to professional organizations in which Willson was a member, held office, or attended meetings. The second subseries contains papers relating to Willson's teaching work at the University of Texas at Austin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs include images of A. Leslie Willson, German authors, and other colleagues. A disbound album contains photographs of German authors taken by Willson during a trip to Germany in 1979; these photographs are identified on versos and in an accompanying list made by Willson. Slides showing German authors, artists, and their works were apparently used by Willson in teaching. A group of slides titled "Author/Artist Slides & Author Portraits" is accompanied by a list made by Willson. Visual art consists of drawings, prints, and posters, with some related photographs and printed reproductions. Most relate to visual art published in Dimension or by Eremiten-Presse (Düsseldorf, Germany). Some items are inscribed to Willson or are accompanied by related writings and correspondence.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: Photographs and Slides; and Visual Art.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: See also: Visual Art and Series I, Subject Files

Grieshaber (woodcuts, Eremiten-Presse); Gerhard Grimm (prints and calendars, 1977); Aldona Gustas; Ludwig Harig and Cecil King, (Galway: Kinvara Press); Roger Herman (1970); Wolfgang Hildesheimerl; Günter Kunert; Christoph Meckel; Erica Pedretti; Peter Weiss (Bo Cavefors Bokförlag, 1963)

P. Grieshaber (Margarethe Hannsmann, Blei im Gefieder, Eremiten-Presse); Roger Herman; Hugo Loetscher (Diogenes Verlag); Peter Pabisch

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into five subseries: Lists by A. Leslie Willson, Reel-to-Reel Tapes, Videocassettes, Cassette Tapes, and Long-Playing Records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Most materials are sound recordings of lectures, Gruppe 47 conferences, readings by authors, Hörspiele (radio plays), or interviews of authors by Willson. A small number of unidentified videocassettes are present. Accompanied by item-level lists made by Willson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A note, dated April 5, 1973, is included with the audiotape reel. It reads: Dr. Willson: Sir, thought maybe you would like to have the tape of Guenter Grass I made of a "Channel 9" program one time-about Spring of '71, I believe. He reads a couple of his poems, one unpublished, gives some "background detail"* of his life which you have already given us, and speaking both in English and German, makes a political speech. (Sorry, but I'd never especially thought he was that great-I read the 'wrong' poem first, or stopped reading too soon or something, but one of those poems in "Gleisdrieck" "turned me off", possibly upon re-reading the book, it was my own bad translation of the poem! But when I did the tape, I was trying to 'see' him as you presented him so enthusiastically in "Dimension"...so you gather he's not my 'greatest' personality as a poet - maybe he is, and I just don't see "all" of him...but I even considered "Katz und Maus" a tragedy, and they said on the cover of English translation it was a comedy! and so I stuck with having read the German version and didn't go any further). So keep the tape, please, if it is of interest to you at all and you happen not to already have it...with my "Yevtushenlo" and "Akhmatova" tapes I wouldn't part for anything. Grass I'll probably never play again, and anyway made a part tape of his poetry readings, in case I wanted it later, on my daughter's small recorder. Let's see, my recorder is a Wollensak, which I think is the same as the one you had in class - did the tape at a speed of 3 3/4, and it is rolled back on tape for playing (well, I dont really know anything about doing this sort of thing ... and only had to learn to "get it on tape", so I could 'survive' Ger. 406, as I didn't have all that much time to spend in U.T. tapelabs. PLEASE DO KEEP THE TAPE, as I have no special use for it.
*dedicated to the memory of Walt Disney__isn't that beautiful of him?
